body_text.text: Lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is one of the most common spinal disorders affecting the elderly (1).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Degenerative changes in the posterior structures of the lumbar spine, such as hypertrophy of the facet joints and ligamentum flavum (LF), in combination with degenerative spondylolisthesis, can contribute to the development of LSS (2).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The hypertrophy of the LF has been described in anatomic studies to be 7-to 8-mm-thick in patients with central stenosis, as opposed to the usual 4 mm or less (2).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Although it is agreed that spinal mechanical stress (3) and secreted cytokines (4) from the herniated disk accelerate the hypertrophy of the LF, which contributes to the development of LSS, the detailed underlying mechanisms are not yet fully understood.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Continuous mechanical stress causes degeneration of the LF (5,6).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Common pathological characteristics in the degenerated LF are the loss of elastic fibers and tissue fibrosis, and increased collagen in tissues (6)(7)(8).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Mechanical stress increases the production of transforming growth factor (TGF)-β1 in several cell lines, including LF cells isolated from surgically resected LF (9,10).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: TGF-β1 is a key factor in the pathogenesis of tissue fibrosis (11) and is abundantly expressed in hypertrophied degenerative LF tissues from LSS (12)(13)(14).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: TGF-β1 increases collagen expression in LF cells (15).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These previous studies suggest that TGF-β1 plays an important role in the hypertrophy of the LF and thus in the pathogenesis of LSS.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, the molecular mechanisms underling the association between TGF-β1 and LF hypertrophy, particularly the mechanisms underlying the TGF-β1-induced increase in collagen expression have not yet been fully elucidated.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Recently, connective tissue growth factor (CTGF) has been shown to have an increased expression in hypertrophied lumbar LF and to be involved in the hypertrophy of the LF (16).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: CTGF is a pro-fibrotic factor involved in the fibrotic process, such as cell proliferation, migration, adhesion and extracellular matrix (ECM) accumulation (17).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: CTGF has also been reported to be involved in the biological activities of TGF-β1.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For example, TGF-β1, in association with CTGF, has been shown to regulate cell proliferation and the synthesis of ECM components (16)(17)(18).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: TGF-β1 also induces the mRNA expression of CTGF in human skin fibroblasts (19).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: TGF-β1 is also a well-known inducer of ECM components, such as collagen
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: and fibronectin (20).
body_text.section: TGF-β1, in association with the increased expression of connective tissue growth factor, induce the hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum through the p38 MAPK pathway

body_text.text: In the presence of CTGF neutralizing antibody (NA), the pro-fibrogenic effects of TGF-β1, such as collagen deposition and anchorage-independent growth are attenuated in fibroblasts (20).
body_text.section: TGF-β1, in association with the increased expression of connective tissue growth factor, induce the hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum through the p38 MAPK pathway

body_text.text: Additionally, mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) have been reported to be involved in the regulation of the expression of CTGF (21,22).
body_text.section: TGF-β1, in association with the increased expression of connective tissue growth factor, induce the hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum through the p38 MAPK pathway

body_text.text: However, whether the expression of CTGF is regulated by TGF-β1 in LF cells and whether it is involved in the hypertrophy of the LF though the MAPK pathway remains unknown.
body_text.section: TGF-β1, in association with the increased expression of connective tissue growth factor, induce the hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum through the p38 MAPK pathway

body_text.text: In this study, we examined the viability of cultured human LF cells, the roles of TGF-β1/CTGF in the proliferation of LF cells and LF hypertrophy, as well as the role of the MAPK pathway in the pathogenesis of LSS by measuring the expression of CTGF and ECM components (collagen I and collagen III) in TGF-β1-treated LF cells obtained from LF tissues of patients who treated with posterior pedicle fixation for lumbar fracture or with a standard nucleotomy for lumbar disc herniation using the Love method.
body_text.section: TGF-β1, in association with the increased expression of connective tissue growth factor, induce the hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum through the p38 MAPK pathway

body_text.text: Specimens from 13 patients, who were treated with posterior pedicle fixation for lumbar fracture or with a standard nucleotomy for lumbar disc herniation using the Love method at Zhujiang Hospital of Southern Medical University, Guangzhou, China, were collected.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: Informed consent was obtained from each patient, and this study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Southern Medical University.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: Cell isolation and culture.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The cells were isolated from the LF tissues as previously described (23,24).
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: Briefly, the specimens were minced with microdissection scissors under aseptic conditions and washed extensively with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) to remove the blood component.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The minced tissue was digested at 37˚C for 60 min with 0.2% type I collagenase (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) in serumfree Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM; Gibco, Sydney, Australia).
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The collagenase-treated ligament chips were washed with serum-containing DMEM to inhibit collagenase activity.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The cells were then filtered through a sterile nylon mesh filter (75 µm pore size), and placed in 35-mm Petri dishes at a density of approximately 5x10 4 cells/ml in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (Gibco).
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The cultures were incubated at 37˚C in a humidified atmosphere, air 95% and CO 2 5%.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The medium was changed at 2-day intervals, and the explants were examined daily for cell outgrowth using an inverted light microscope (IX83; Olympus, Tokyo, Japan).
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The outgrown cells were harvested before confluence and subcultured after trypsinization with 0.2% trypsin/0.02% ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA).
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The cells at the third-fifth passage were used for the experiments.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: Immunofluorescence staining for collagen I and III, and fibronectin was used to identify the phenotype of the cultured LF cells.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: Viability of cultured LF cells.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The viability of the LF cells was evaluated using the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-y1)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) (MTT) (Sigma-Aldrich) colorimetric assay, that is based on the reduction of formazan crystals by living cells (25).
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: Briefly, LF cells at passages 1, 3, and 5 were seeded in 96-well tissue culture plates at 2x10 4 cells/well and incubated at 37˚C under 5% CO 2 for 0, 24, 48 and 72 h.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: The cells was then washed with PBS and subsequently incubated in 100 µl of 5 mg/ml MTT solution (Invitrogen Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA) for 3 h.
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: MTT was converted into purple colored formazan in living cells, which was then solubilized with dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (Invitrogen) and the absorbance of the solution was measured at 450 nm using a microplate reader (Thermo Plate; Rayto Life and Analytical Science Co., Ltd., Shenzhen, China).
body_text.section: Samples.

body_text.text: To examine the biological response of human LF cells to TGF-β1/CTGF, the LF cell cultures were treated with 3 ng/ml TGF-β1 or 50 ng/ml CTGF (R&D Systems, Minneapolis, MN, USA) in the absence or presence of CTGF NAs (1:500) for 24 h.
body_text.section: Effect of TGF-β1/CTGF on LF cells.

body_text.text: The proliferation of the LF cells was first examined by MTT assay, and the mRNA expression levels of CTGF, collagen I and collagen III were then detected by reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR), and the protein expression of CTGF in the cell lysate was detected by western blot analysis.
body_text.section: Effect of TGF-β1/CTGF on LF cells.

body_text.text: To investigate the role of the MAPK pathway in the TGF-β1-induced expression of CTGF, collagen I and collagen III, the LF cell cultures were treated with various MAPK inhibitors including, the JNK inhibitor, SP600125 (10 µΜ), the ERK inhibitor, PD985059 (10 µΜ), and the p38 inhibitor, SB203580 (100 µΜ), (all from Sigma-Aldrich).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The cells were pre-treated with the indicated MAPK inhibitors for 1 h, and were then treated with 3 ng/ml of TGF-β1 for 24 h.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The mRNA expression levels of CTGF, collagen I and collagen III were then detected by RT-qPCR.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: In addition, to further confirm the role of p38, we examined the expression of p38 and p-p38 in the cells following treatment with 3 ng/ml TGF-β1 for 2, 4, and 6 h by immunofluorescence staining, and examined the protein expression of p38 and p-p38 in the cells following treatment with 3 ng/ml TGF-β1 for 30 min, 1, 2, and 3 h by western blot analysis.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Validation of the critical role of p38 using p38 siRNA.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The involvement of p38 in the TGF-β1-induced expression of CTGF, collagen I and collagen III was further examined using the siRNA-mediated knockdown of p38.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: For transfection with p38 siRNA or non-targeting negative control (Santa Cruz Biotechnology Inc., Santa Cruz, CA, USA), DharmaFECT reagent (Invitrogen Life Technologies) was used according to the manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: After 24 h, the culture medium was replaced with fresh supplemented medium, and the cells were cultivated for an additional 24 h following treatment with 3 ng/ml TGF-β1 for 6 h.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The expression levels of p38 and p-p38 were detected by immunofluorescence staining, and the transfection efficiency over time (0, 12, 24, 36 h) was also validated by RT-PCR (data not shown).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The mRNA expression levels of CTGF, collagen I, and collagen III were detected by RT-qPCR.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The protein expression of CTGF was detected by western blot analysis.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: RT-qPCR.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Following the afore-mentioned incubation or treatments, total RNA was extracted from the cells using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen Life Technologies).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: A total of 2 µg of total RNA was used to synthesize complementary DNA (cDNA) using M-MLV Reverse Transcriptase (Takara, Dalian, China), and subjected to RT-qPCR using SYBR-Green real-time master mix (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan) with the following primers: 5'-GGAGTGGGTGTGTGACGAG-3' (forward) and 5'-GTC TTCCAGTCGGTAAGCCG-3' (reverse) for CTGF; 5'-AGATC TGAAGTGTGATGACTCAGG-3' (forward) and 5'-CAGAT CACGTCATCGCACAAC-3' (reverse) for collagen I; 5'-ATGT TCCACGGAAACACTGG-3' (forward) and 5'-GGAGAG AAGTCGAAGGAATGC-3' (reverse) for collagen III; CGTGT TGCAGATCCAGACCA (forward) and GCCAGAATGC AGCCTACAGA and (reverse) for p38 siRNA; and 5'-ACACCC ACTCCTCCACCTTT-3' (forward) and 5'-TTACTCCTTGG AGGCCATGT-3' (reverse) for GAPDH.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The thermal treatment was 15 min at 95˚C, followed by 35 cycles of 15 sec at 95˚C, 30 sec at 60˚C, and 30 sec at 72˚C.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Gene expression was normalized to the level of GAPDH within each sample using the relative ΔΔCT method.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Gene expression is shown as the expression relative to the control.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The data shown are representative of 3 independent experiments.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Western blot analysis.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The LF cells were lysed using SDS lysis buffer (Beyotime, Shanghai, China) and centrifuged at 14,000 x g for 10 min at 4˚C.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Equal amounts of proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE on a 10% gel and then transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane, followed by blocking with 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) for 1 h at room temperature.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The membrane was then incubated overnight at 4˚C with rabbit monoclonal antibody specific to CTGF (1:400; ab6992), p-p38 (1:1,000; ab47363), or p38 (1:400; ab27986).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: All antibodies were purchased from Abcam (Cambridge, MA, USA).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Following 3 washes, the membrane was incubated with anti-rabbit IgG conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (A0208; Beyotime) for 1 h at room temperature.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Detection was performed with luminal chemiluminescent systems.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Quantitative data were obtained using a computing densitometer and MultiGauge software version 3.0 (Fuji Photo Film Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: #4412; Cell Signaling Technology, Inc., Danvers, MA, USA) for 30 min at room temperature.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Immunofluorescence staining was imaged using a Zeiss LSM 510 laser scanning confocal microscope (Zeiss, Jena, Germany) as previously described (26).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Immunofluorescence staining.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: The LF cells were rapidly washed once with PBS and fixed with 2% paraformaldehyde, blocked with 2% goat serum (GS; C0265; Beyotime) for 30 min, stained with rabbit anti-collagen I (1:100; Ab34710; Abcam), anti-collagen III (1:100; Ab7778; Abcam), anti-fibronectin (1:100; Ab2413; Abcam), p-p38 (1:100), or anti-p38 (1:200) antibodies, and finally visualized with Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-rabbit antibody (1:150; #4412; Cell Signaling Technology, Inc., Danvers, MA, USA) for 30 min at room temperature.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Immunofluorescence staining was imaged using a Zeiss LSM 510 laser scanning confocal microscope (Zeiss, Jena, Germany) as previously described (26).

body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: All data are expressed as the means ± standard error of the mean (SEM).
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with Fisher's protected LSD post-hoc test was performed to test the difference in densitometeric data.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.text: Non-parametric one sample Wilcoxon test was used for the analysis of the results of RT-qPCR.
body_text.section: Determination of the role of the MAPK pathway.

body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: Human lumbar LF cells were isolated from surgical specimens obtained from 13 patients and cultured.
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: Immunofluorescence staining was used to identify the cell phenotype (Fig. 1).
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: The cultured cells had a typical LF cell phenotype, and uniformly expressed collagen I collagen and fibronectin in each cell, and very few cells expressed type III collagen.
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: Cell proliferation assay revealed that there were no significant differences in cell prolifaration among the LF cell subcultures (passages 1, 3 and 5) at any experimental time point (0, 24, 48, or 72 h) (P>0.05; Fig. 2).
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: There was no significant difference in cell bioactivities between the individual donors (data not shown).
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: During the 72-h time period, the proliferation of the LF cells was significantly increased with time in each subculture, showing a similar viability with the primary cultured LF cells (Fig. 2).
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: Both TGF-β1 and CTGF markedly elevated the proliferation of the LF cells ( Fig. 3).
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: Of note, the effects of TGF-β1 and CTGF on the proliferation of the LF cells were attenuated by CTGF NA, suggesting that TGF-β1 associates with CTGF.
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: TGF-β1/CTGF induce the mRNA expression of CTGF, collagen I and collagen III, and the expression of CTGF in cell lysate.
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: TGF-β1 increased the mRNA expression of CTGF, and this effect was markedly abolished by CTGF NA (Fig. 4A).
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: To further evaluate the role of TGF-β1/CTGF in the hypertrophy of the LF, we determined the mRNA expression of ECM components, such as collagen I (Fig. 4B) and collagen III (Fig. 4C).
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: TGF-β1/CTGF significantly increased the mRNA expression of collagen I and collagen III.
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: In addition, the presence of CTGF NA abrogated the promoting effects of TGF-β1/CTGF on the mRNA expression of collagen I and collagen III ( Fig. 4B  and C).
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: We also examined the expression of CTGF in the cell lysate (Fig. 4D).
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: CTGF expression in the cell lysate was increased in the presence of TGF-β1 and CTGF, and was diminished by the addition of CTGF NA.
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: Overall, these findings suggest that TGF-β1/CTGF plays an important role in the hypertrophy of the LF.
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: In addition, it is worthwhile to note that exogenous CTGF did not enhance the mRNA expression of CTGF in the LF cells ( Fig. 4A), but it increased the expression of CTGF in the cell lysate ( Fig. 4D), indicating that although CTGF was exogenously expressed in the LF cells, it did not increase the CTGF mRNA level.
body_text.section: TGF-β1/CTGF enhances the proliferation of human lumbar LF cells.

body_text.text: Importantly, CTGF NA abolished the promoting effects of TGF-β1 on CTGF expression.

body_text.text: Stenotic LF cells can produce a matrix rich in type I and III collagen and fibronectin (23), and the cultured cells acquire the LF cell phenotype with the uniform expression of collagen I and type III collagen, as well as fibronectin in each cell.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Hypertrophy of the LF plays an important role in the development of LSS (2).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Spinal mechanical stress (3) and secreted cytokines (4) from herniated disk accelerate the hypertrophy of the LF.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Mechanical stress increases the production of TGF-β1 (9,10).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The association between TGF-β1 and LF hypertrophy has not yet been fully elucidated.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In this study, we found that TGF-β1 enhanced the expression of CTGF at both the mRNA and protein level, further supporting the existence of an interaction between CTGF and TGF-β1, as described in a previous study (27).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Furthermore, TGF-β1 elevated the mRNA expression of ECM components, including collagen I and III, and this effect was abolished by the CTGF NA, indicating that TGF-β1 contributes to the hypertrophy of the LF in association with CTGF.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Furthermore, the associations between TGF-β1, CTGF and LF hypertrophy are mediated through the p38 MAPK pathway.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Previous studies have demonstrated that TGF-β1, in association with CTGF, regulates cell proliferation (16,18).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In this study, we found that TGF-β1 enhanced the proliferation of LF cells, and this associated with an increase in CTGF expression.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: However, with the addition of CTGF NA, the promoting effects of TGF-β1 on the proliferation of LF cells were abrogated (Fig. 3).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Furthermore, TGF-β1, in association with CTGF, regulates the synthesis of ECM components (16,18).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The increased synthesis of collagen is a major characteristic of LF hypertrophy (10).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: LF cells have a typical fibroblastlike phenotype, as they express type I and type III collagen and fibronectin, but do not stain positive for osteonectin (23).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Normal cells do not synthesize type II collagen (23).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Type I and type III collagen have been found to be predominant in human LF (28).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In this study, we also observed that TGF-β1 increased the mRNA expression of collagen I and collagen III, and this effect was abrogated by CTGF NA, indicating that the TGF-β1-induced synthesis of ECM components is associated with CTGF.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: TGF-β1 elevated the expression of CTGF at both the mRNA and protein level (Fig. 4).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Therefore, TGF-β1, in association with CTGF, contributed to the hypertrophy of the LF.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In general, the effects of TGF-β are mediated through the phosphorylation of cytoplasmic R-Smads (29,30).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In addition to the activation of Smad signaling, TGF-β1 can activate members of the MAPK pathway, as well as other kinases (31,32).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Upon stimulation with TGF-β, the crosstalk between the ERK, p38, JNK and Smad pathways is cell type-specific (33,34).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Previous studies have shown the pro-fibrotic activities of p38 and ERK signaling, and the anti-fibrotic activities of JNK signaling (27).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The pathway involved in the TGF-β1-induced hypertrophy of the LF has not been addressed to date, to the best of our knowledge.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In this study, among ERK, p38, and JNK, only the use of the p38 inhibitor abolished the mRNA expression of CTGF, and collagen I and III (Fig. 5), indicating the profibrotic activities of p38 signaling.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: We further observed that the expression and phosphorylation level of p38 were enhanced by TGF-β1.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Following the silencing of p38 MAPK (its efficiency over time was almost the same; data not shown), the expression and phosphorylation level of p38, as well as the mRNA expression of CTGF, collagen I and collagen III were attenuated correspondingly, as well as the expression of CTGF (Fig. 6).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Apparently, the expression of p38 and p-p38 presented in Fig. 6A does not match that shown in Fig. 6B.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It is worth noting that the immunofluorescence staining in this study was focused on the cell surface, that should limit the detection of intracellular signaling, but the western blot analysis included all the intracellular and cell surface information.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These results further confirm that p38 MAPK is a key mediator of the effects of TGF-β1, and the pro-fibrotic activities of p38 signaling.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In conclusion, TGF-β1, in association with the increased expression of CTGF, induce the hypertrophy of the LF through the p38 MAPK pathway.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Degenerative changes in the posterior structures of the lumbar spine, such as the hypertrophy of the facet joints and LF, in combination with degenerative spondylolisthesis, contribute to the development of LSS (2).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Patients with LSS usually present with the typical symptoms of neurogenic claudication and/or lumbar or sacral radiculopathy (35,36).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Many patients may also complain of pain when performing activities requiring the extension of the spine.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These symptoms may improve with appropriate conservative treatment, although 60-85% of patients undergo surgical treatments (35).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our observations appear to be important for evaluating the pathomechanisms of LSS, and may prove to be helpful in the diagnosis and prevention of LSS in the early stage, and may also provide an effective alternative to surgery.
body_text.section: Discussion
